text: Welcome, everybody.
Thank you so much for coming.
It is so good to see you.

I'm seeing a number of
new faces and many--
I won't say old faces, but--
[LAUGHTER]
--returning faces.

Some of you, I think,
have been here--

coming every year
since the beginning.

We had one year during
COVID when we didn't meet,

and then we had one
virtual session.

But we have been
meeting for 10 years.

This is-- yeah, it
was 10 years ago

that we had our first Gender
and Work Research Symposium.
So that was in 2013.

And that was part of a
year-long celebration

of 50 years since the admission
of women to the two-year MBA
program.

We didn't really think of it as
something that would be annual,

but then shortly after that
we founded the HBS Gender

Initiative, and that gave
an institutional home
for the conference.

So we said, OK, let's
just do it every year.

So that was the
Gender Initiative.
And good news.

We have been allowed to
change our name, finally.

About four years in the making,
but we are now more accurately,

I think, represented with the
name Race, Gender, and Equity.

And insiders, we call that
the RaGE, our little a-G-E.

[LAUGHS] We don't
say that too publicly

because the dean's office
wasn't super excited about that.
[LAUGHTER]

But I did think that we should
be outraged about inequality.
So anyway, new name.
Same mission.
OK.

So I know it's
customary to do what

I'm about to do at the
end of the conference,

but I would like to start
by giving a big thank you
to my team.

And that is, as you
all have known--

Colleen and I were
talking this morning--

but it's been 10 years,
although she's actually
been working with us longer.

So Colleen Ammerman and
Ethi Al-Mahdi over there.
And we have--
[APPLAUSE]

We have also grown this
year, and so we have
some new people on our team.

We have a new
associate director.

Well, we have an
associate director,

which, we did not have
that position before,
and that is Daniella Diniz.

And also several
research associates.
So Aparna Sridaran.
Am I saying that right?
I think.

And Rhea Manoharan
and Izzy Yeoh.

And I think they're
all back there.
I see Rhea.

[LAUGHS] You should
kind of step out.
Let people see you.
I don't know.
That's Rhea.
[APPLAUSE]

I don't know where--
where's Aparna?

Anyway, you will see them around
and they are part of our team.
OK.

So let me say a few words
about the conference theme.

So last year, we took up
Audre Lorde's question,

what does it mean when the
tools of a racist patriarchy

are used to examine the
fruits of the same patriarchy?

She was not helpful
in her answer.

And now offering her
now famous statement,

"The master's tools will never
dismantle the master's house."

And so last year, we examined
together four master's tools.

Capitalism, gender as in the
gender binary, DEI initiatives,

and higher ed, specifically
Smith College and Morehouse

College as a women's college
and a Black men's college,
respectively.

So we considered whether
and how these tools

offered any potential to
dismantle the structures
and consequences of oppression.

I think the discussions
were really generative.
All the talks were amazing.

And I would say on balance,
we were largely pessimistic
about these tools.
[LAUGHTER]

I would say less so for
Smith and Morehouse.

But that raised for us this
question, if not the master's
tools, then what?

And so that's the question
that our team grappled with.

And it took a while,
I have to say.

Many discussions among all of
us, those people I just named.

And we came up with this theme,
which we're quite happy with.

Tools for Humanity:
Rage and Love

as Acts of Resistance
and Renewal,

which we kind of pose
as a counterpoint
to last year's theme.
OK.
So why tools for humanity?

Because that's
what we believe is

at stake with inequality,
our collective humanity.

And so just inequality
takes a toll

on our individual and
our collective humanity,

so that's kind of
where we start.

And then we thought,
we really need

something that taps into our
hearts as well as our heads.

And so that brought us to
the question, what would it

mean if we were to
allow ourselves to feel

into the feelings of
doing the work that we do,

aiming to change the world
from within the walls

of the master's house, and to
feel the parts of our humanity
that we so often ignore?

So our emotions,
our vulnerability,

our capacity for real
human care and compassion.

And these are parts of
ourselves that I think we rarely

attend to, and yet they
are part and parcel

of who we are and of the work
that we do at whatever level,

even if we're at the
structural level, right?

Because we are the instruments
of structural change.

That's how we came
upon rage and love,

and they seemed to be
kind of like flip sides
of the same coin.

And we thought that if we
interrogated these, that
might hold a lot of promise.

So we want to examine rage,
as in Brittney Cooper's words,

"a legitimate
political emotion" that

is deeply racialized
and gendered,

the kind of anger that is
"a response to instances

of injustice" in the
words of Myisha Cherry.

We will be hearing from
her tomorrow morning.

And then love as in
bell hooks' notion

of "the practice of love" being
"the most powerful antidote

to the politics of
domination" and "a path

to personal and
political recovery."
OK.

So bringing these
two together, let

me share a reflection on anger
by the Irish poet David Whyte

that my friend Lisa Lahey
turned me on to a few weeks ago.
So I'm going to--

I'm going to read it to
you while I show it here.

So "Anger," he says, "is the
deepest form of compassion

for another, for the world,
for the self, for a life,

for the body, for a
family, for all our ideals.

Stripped of physical
imprisonment

and violent reaction, anger
is the purest form of care.

The internal living
flame of anger

always illuminates
what we belong to,

what we wish to
protect, and what

we are willing to
hazard ourselves for.

What we usually
call anger is only

what is left of
its essence when we

are overwhelmed by
its accompanying

vulnerability, when it reaches
the lost surface of our mind

or our body's
incapacity to hold it,

or when it touches the
limits of our understanding.

Anger in its pure
form is the measure

of the way we are implicated
in the world, made

vulnerable through love
in all its specifics."

That just seemed to
really bring together

both sides of this in
such a beautiful way.

So we've organized our
panels and our keynotes
around these themes.

And to do that, we had to reach
pretty far beyond our networks.

And we are bringing you, I
think, a quite even more broad

range of scholars and public
intellectuals and activists
than we normally do.

And they're going
to share with us how

these themes have informed
and animate their work.

So I'm going to now turn it
over to my co-conspirator,
[LAUGHS] Lakshmi Ramarajan.
[APPLAUSE]
Thank you, Robin.
Good morning.
Welcome.

It's always such a pleasure to
see old friends, meet new ones,

and to learn together
at this conference.

It's one of the favorite
parts of my year,

and I hope it is for
all of you as well.

Last year, as
Robin said, when we

were thinking about
this conference,

and what next and
what comes after
and we came up with this title--

I won't say a lot
more than what Robin

said because her framing
and her grounding

is always a source
of inspiration.

But these are the
couple of thoughts

that came up for
me just as I was
thinking about this morning.

And in a fairly
simplistic way, I

think part of what for me the
agenda was with rage and love

was rage isn't bad and
love isn't good, right?
So can we complexify it?

Can we interrogate, as
Robin said, these ideas,

and think about rage, moving
from rage that gives rise

to these oppressive,
dehumanizing systems

to rage that gives
rise to resistance

and destruction
of those systems,

and potentially generativity
for all of humanity?
Love, again, right?

This called up for me the
Martin Luther King quote.

"Power without love is
reckless and abusive,

and love without power is
sentimental and anemic."

So we don't want that
second kind of love.

We want love with
power, a lot of power,

maybe animated by a
lot of rage, right?

And so I'm very excited
to learn from our speakers

and from each other at
our discussion tables

about how rage
and love hopefully

are these fundamental--
and this is

calling in sort of Rae's
talk that's coming up--

how rage and love
are fundamental

emotional, social, embodied
channels for embracing our own
and others' humanity.
So that's what I'm hoping for.

I just have two
things to tee up.

One is the ITC, which is our
workshop at the end of the day
tomorrow.
I know.

We're moving from starting off
the conference to the ending
already.

But this is just to seed
some thoughts for us.

It's going to be led by
our wonderful Lisa Lahey.

It's the "Immunity
To Change" workshop.

And how it relates, I
think, for us in the theme

is to go back to this first
before the colon idea,
the tools for humanity.

And as Robin was saying,
we have all these multiple,

complex parts of
ourselves and who

we are, and we live
in institutions,

in roles, in systems
that make us cut off
different parts of ourselves.

And so hopefully, when
you think about this

as a tool for humanity, you
can think about in a couple
of ways, right?

That the ITC is one
potential tool for helping us

think about all these
conflicted, different parts
of ourselves that are at odds.

And how do we surface
them and think about them?

And then potentially as a way
to make ourselves into, if we do

that integrative work, a
tool for humanity in terms
of trying to create the change.

So to get us
thinking about that,

we have these sticky
pads at the table.

You'll see these colorful sticky
pads and pens and sharpies.

And as you hear the
speakers and engage

in your table discussions,
what we'd love for you to do

is just write down, what
does it spark in you?
What emotions?
What thoughts?
What reactions?
What questions?

And we have these
two whiteboards,

if you'd just go put them
up, paste them up there.

And we'll collect these
through the day today

and through the
morning tomorrow,

and then we'll
take a look at them

tomorrow when Lisa
does the workshops.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
